awd_titl_txt: Materials Research Science and Engineering Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
****Nontechnical abstract****
The Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at the University of Chicago supports innovative research to produce the design principles for the next generation of materials. The research is focused on investigating materials formed far from equilibrium, exploring new paradigms for material fabrication and response, and exploiting feedback between structure and dynamics. Senior investigators come from eleven University Departments and Institutes, as well as neighboring Argonne National Laboratory and PREM partner, the City College of New York. The Center's shared facilities provide vital support for its research and further support the broader materials research community by granting access to external users. The Center's collaborations with industry, national laboratories and international partners serve to engage those entities in research with the Center, and expand opportunities for MRSEC students. The Management Laboratory, run with the Chicago Booth School of Business, and industrial internships provide professional development opportunities for MRSEC students. In addition to training a diverse group of students, the Chicago MRSEC brings science inquiry experiences to underserved students in neighboring communities on Chicago's South Side including programs for students and teachers and after-school Science Clubs. The MRSEC provides summer research opportunities to undergraduates from all over the US and high school students from the South Side of Chicago. As part of its outreach to the general public, the MRSEC collaborates with Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry and the Exploratorium in San Francisco to develop materials science exhibits. The MRSEC is committed to increasing the Center diversity as reflected in the significant participation by women in the Center's investigators and leadership.

****Technical abstract****
Research is organized in three Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs): (i) The IRG on Dynamics at Soft Interfaces focus on both scientific challenges and technological opportunities that arise from controlling and manipulating how much or how fast a soft interface forms or deforms. The research endeavors to establish the link between the interface dynamics and the properties of the material as a whole, which opens up opportunities for designing specific material responses and provides a pathway towards innovative applications. (ii) The IRG on Spatiotemporal Control of Active Materials aims to understand, design, and synthesize materials containing distributed molecular elements that convert chemical energy into mechanical work. Its goal is to achieve control of active materials and ultimately to create novel molecular assemblies for robust tunable shape change. (iii) The IRG on Engineering Quantum Materials and Interactions seeks to elucidate the critical issues of control and coherence in both individual and in collective-mode quantum systems, with the intention of manipulating and exploiting quantum coherence in materials over a large range of length scales. Goals include advancing applications in quantum sensing, fabricating materials for quantum information as well as creating the next generation of characterization tools for traditional materials.

The Management Laboratory, run with the Chicago Booth School of Business, and industrial internships provide professional development opportunities for MRSEC students. In addition to training a diverse group of students, the Chicago MRSEC brings science inquiry experiences to underserved students in neighboring communities on Chicago's South Side including programs for students and teachers and after-school Science Clubs. The MRSEC provides summer research opportunities to undergraduates from all over the US and high school students from the South Side of Chicago. As part of its outreach to the general public, the MRSEC collaborates with Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry and the Exploratorium in San Francisco to develop materials science exhibits. The MRSEC is committed to increasing the Center diversity as reflected in the significant participation by women in the Center's investigators and leadership.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The University of Chicago MRSEC has established a highly successful, multidisciplinary approach to address issues of technological importance at the forefront of materials research. The overarching goal, shared by our three Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs), was to generate the design principles for new generations of materials. Each of the three IRGs addressed fundamental questions applicable to a broad class of systems. We therefore did not delineate IRGs by the specific type of material investigated, but by the conceptual framework they addressed. This enabled us to explore synergistic connections effectively and to attack some of the deepest challenges of materials research. Common themes included investigating materials formed far from equilibrium, exploring new paradigms for material fabrication and response, and exploiting feedback between structure and dynamics. These themes, reappearing in each IRG, dealt with important basic problems that explored design concepts that were far from conventional and whose prospects were far from certain. These endeavors were thus highly risky, but success was likely to bring a comparably high payoff.  Satisfactory progress was expected to open new fields of research and launch new paradigms for materials fabrication. 

The IRG on Dynamics at Soft Interfaces focused on both scientific challenges and technological opportunities that arose from controlling and manipulating how fast and to what extent a soft interface forms or deforms, with systems ranging from nanoscale colloids to suspensions of micron-scale particles to truly macroscopic granular materials. By examining how stress variations at an interface could alter properties in the bulk and, conversely, how tailoring bulk parameters could guide interfacial dynamics, the research endeavored to establish the link between processes occurring at the interface and the properties of the material as a whole. The IRG on Control of Active and Shape-Changing Materials aimed to understand and exploit the myriad ways that biology has evolved to construct materials that spontaneously change shape or generate force.  A key feature of such biological materials was that they contained distributed molecular elements that converted chemical energy into mechanical work, and a central question this IRG sought to address was how such activity related to specific materials properties.   The IRG on Engineering Quantum Materials and Interactions sought to elucidate the critical issues of control and coherence in both individual and in collective-mode quantum systems, with the goal of the manipulation and exploitation of quantum coherence in materials over a large range of length scales, from individual quantum centers to macroscopically entangled materials. 

The center also supported Seed/Super-seed Projects that explored innovative directions with the potential for opening up new research avenues for the Center. Towards the end of the award, the first funded "super-seed" sought to develop novel means to construct hybrid materials through bottom-up engineering with  novel forms of energy and heat transport. The second super-seed focused on memory and aging in materials.  And the seed developed new ways to construct functionally-graded semiconductor thin films.  

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The UChicago MRSEC measured its impact in terms of its ability to (1) establish highly collaborative efforts to push the frontiers of materials science and engineering; (2) adopt highly original and unorthodox approaches to address grand challenges in materials research; (3) create an inclusive environment to collaborate on materials science problems.  MRSEC-supported research for this award has resulted in over 440 publications, 106 with MRSEC listed as primary support. Of these publications, 25% were co-authored by 2 or more MRSEC PIs. Most importantly, the impact of the MRSEC on collaborative materials science research at UChicago extended beyond this metric, including, for example, work performed by joint students/postdocs who may not have listed both advisers in publications and theoretical findings that preceded or proceeded from experimental work. 

 

BROADER IMPACTS

The integration of Research, Education, Outreach and Diversity is essential to the MRSEC?s mission. Our highly successful REU program introduced 42 women and 35 underrepresented minorities to materials research.  We partnered with CCNY, a minority serving institution on research and education.  Our expertise was disseminated to industry, expanding opportunities for our students. We cultivated research partnerships with Cabot Microelectronics, Particulate Solids Research, Inc., Samsung, and IBM Almaden.  

We provided materials science courses to Chicago Public School teachers through the Seminars for Endorsement of Science and Mathematics Educators program. A collaboration with the Lindblom Math and Science Academy brought 3-5 underrepresented minority high school students to our Center each summer for internships. Our MRSEC organized after-school Science Clubs to mentor students interested in science at neighborhood schools serving low-income, underrepresented minorities. We invited the public to our Center for an annual Holiday Lecture and Open House with a demo show, lab tours, and a hands-on demo space. Finally, our MRSEC collaborated with The Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago and the Exploratorium in San Francisco to develop exhibits, including "Stress Trees", and the granular materials portion of the exhibit "Science Storms".

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2022
Modified by: Margaret L Gardel
por.por_txt_cntn:
The University of Chicago MRSEC has established a highly successful, multidisciplinary approach to address issues of technological importance at the forefront of materials research. The overarching goal, shared by our three Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs), was to generate the design principles for new generations of materials. Each of the three IRGs addressed fundamental questions applicable to a broad class of systems. We therefore did not delineate IRGs by the specific type of material investigated, but by the conceptual framework they addressed. This enabled us to explore synergistic connections effectively and to attack some of the deepest challenges of materials research. Common themes included investigating materials formed far from equilibrium, exploring new paradigms for material fabrication and response, and exploiting feedback between structure and dynamics. These themes, reappearing in each IRG, dealt with important basic problems that explored design concepts that were far from conventional and whose prospects were far from certain. These endeavors were thus highly risky, but success was likely to bring a comparably high payoff.  Satisfactory progress was expected to open new fields of research and launch new paradigms for materials fabrication. 

The IRG on Dynamics at Soft Interfaces focused on both scientific challenges and technological opportunities that arose from controlling and manipulating how fast and to what extent a soft interface forms or deforms, with systems ranging from nanoscale colloids to suspensions of micron-scale particles to truly macroscopic granular materials. By examining how stress variations at an interface could alter properties in the bulk and, conversely, how tailoring bulk parameters could guide interfacial dynamics, the research endeavored to establish the link between processes occurring at the interface and the properties of the material as a whole. A key feature of such biological materials was that they contained distributed molecular elements that converted chemical energy into mechanical work, and a central question this IRG sought to address was how such activity related to specific materials properties.   The IRG on Engineering Quantum Materials and Interactions sought to elucidate the critical issues of control and coherence in both individual and in collective-mode quantum systems, with the goal of the manipulation and exploitation of quantum coherence in materials over a large range of length scales, from individual quantum centers to macroscopically entangled materials. 

The center also supported Seed/Super-seed Projects that explored innovative directions with the potential for opening up new research avenues for the Center. The UChicago MRSEC measured its impact in terms of its ability to (1) establish highly collaborative efforts to push the frontiers of materials science and engineering; (2) adopt highly original and unorthodox approaches to address grand challenges in materials research; (3) create an inclusive environment to collaborate on materials science problems. Most importantly, the impact of the MRSEC on collaborative materials science research at UChicago extended beyond this metric, including, for example, work performed by joint students/postdocs who may not have listed both advisers in publications and theoretical findings that preceded or proceeded from experimental work. 

 

BROADER IMPACTS

The integration of Research, Education, Outreach and Diversity is essential to the MRSEC?s mission. Our highly successful REU program introduced 42 women and 35 underrepresented minorities to materials research.  We partnered with CCNY, a minority serving institution on research and education.  Our expertise was disseminated to industry, expanding opportunities for our students. We cultivated research partnerships with Cabot Microelectronics, Particulate Solids Research, Inc., Samsung, and IBM Almaden.  

We provided materials science courses to Chicago Public School teachers through the Seminars for Endorsement of Science and Mathematics Educators program. A collaboration with the Lindblom Math and Science Academy brought 3-5 underrepresented minority high school students to our Center each summer for internships. Finally, our MRSEC collaborated with The Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago and the Exploratorium in San Francisco to develop exhibits, including "Stress Trees", and the granular materials portion of the exhibit "Science Storms".
